Award.AwardTitle: Pseudocapacitive and Intercalation Compounds for Water Desalination: Surface Chemistry, Electrode Structure and Foulant Tolerance

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PROPOSAL NO.: 1403826
PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR: Mauter, Meagan
INSTITUTION NAME: Carnegie-Mellon University
TITLE: Pseudocapacitive and Intercalation Compounds for Water Desalination: Surface Chemistry, Electrode Structure and Foulant Tolerance
NSF RECEIVE DATE: 10/29/2013

With only 0.03% of the world's water is suitable potable water for human use, the need for clean water is a current concern that can only become more urgent in the future. While much of the attention has been on desalination of seawater into potable water, the ability to desalinate brackish/briny water (~0.5 to 30 ppt salt) efficiently would be a significant option for water reclamation. If successful, there should be positive economic and water-resource impact of desalination of brackish water, which affects most the in-land water desalination efforts in agricultural, municipal water, and wastewater treatment, where the high recovery rates of capacitive desalination processes are particularly attractive and where post-treatment, or brine disposal, makes low-recovery membrane-based systems expensive. In terms of educational impact, the PI and co-PI will develop an introductory course that focuses on water and energy, integrating engineering and social sociopolitical perspectives (both PI and co-PI hold joint appointments in the Department of Engineering and Public Policy). In addition, the PI and co-PI will incorporate the proposed research into teaching and outreach through participating in the Pittsburgh Water Economy Network and the NAS/NAE Science and Engineering Ambassador Program.

Capacitive de-ionization (CDI), whereby charged species are captured by porous electrodes and then released into a waste stream, is a promising approach for desalination of brackish water; but the technology is limited by the low efficiency of the cation/anion removal cycle and by the tendency of the electrodes to foul. This proposal seeks to replace existing carbon electrode structures with new composite electrode structures that exhibit pseudo-capacitive and/or fast intercalation properties, where the materials quickly capture and release ions from weak faradic reactions. These electrodes will be able to access electrochemical reactions that are significantly denser, from a charge accumulation perspective, thereby allowing for thinner, more efficient electrode structures that are also less susceptible to diminished performance under fouled conditions. The PIs will first select viable candidate materials and evaluate their interfacial charge and ion transfer mechanisms in a relevant pseudocapacitive deionization (PDI) environment. They will then characterize the impact of PDI particle and electrode macro/meso-structures on the performance observed for PDI reactions, followed by evaluations of the performance of PDI surfaces in the presence of model colloidal foul ants, since electrode fouling by colloids and bacteria severely diminishes the ion adsorption capacity of conventional CDI electrodes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF CBET Award 1403826 was awarded to Carnegie Mellon University to explore novel electrochemically active materials and design an electrochemical deionization (EDI) process for water desalination during the period from 2014-2018. This project resulted in three key outcomes that extended our knowledge of electrochemical systems and their application inwater desalination, separation of complex ionic mixtures, and resource recovery.

First, we developed a framework based on key metrics of merit that can be used to systematically evaluate the performance of different configurations of EDI systems. Using this framework, we demonstrated differences between EDI systems that were made with only a pair of electrodes and those that combined electrodes with ion-exchange membranes. Further, we demonstrated that electrode systems paired with ion-exchange membranes offer improved energy efficiency. Next, we furthered understanding of the interactions between different ionic and non-ionic constituents in water with charged electrode surfaces. We demonstrated that salt or ion concentrations in water influence the rates and removal performance of the electrode materials. However, non-ionic constituents such as bacteria, organic compounds and colloids can get attached to the electrode surface and influence the electrode performance. We also determined that the actual behavior of the electrode in presence of these non-ionic constituents is material specific, and in some cases can lead to deterioration of the electrode materials. In these cases, we expect that pretreatment of the feedwater prior to the EDI process may be necessary to increase the lifetime of the electrodes. Finally, we also developed functional electrode materials for selective removal of ionic constituents of interest. A significant result from these materials developments was a novel electrode material that can remove nitrate ions from water, which pose an environmental and health hazard.

Our findings offer great promise in a broad range of applications, including removing nutrients from agricultural drainage, recovering valuable byproducts from waste streams, and desalinating brackish groundwater with high water recovery.  In addition, we identified the origins of energy inefficiencies of electrochemical desalination systems with diverse configurations. Our findings provide crucial guidance for system design and device operation to reduce the energy consumption and environmental impacts of these technologies. Further, our work on diminished desalination performance of electrochemical desalination systems in complex environmental waters allows for a comprehensive evaluation of the techno-economic viability of these technologies in treating brackish water.  Overall, our work paves the way to the development of novel electrochemical desalination systems with tailored performance attributes (such as selective ion removal) and reduced operational cost. Our work identified the limitations of current electrochemical desalination systems for treating complex environmental waters. With continued material improvements and process optimization, we believe that these technologies can be deployed in real world and provide enormous societal benefits, such as providing clean water to rural communities that rely on brackish groundwater, and offsetting the treatment burden for agricultural and industrial waste streams by recovering valuable resources.



Additional information.

We anticipate two additional publications from this project.  These publications involve documentation of the advantages and limitations of carbon electrodes with various structures in capacitive desalination, identification of a novel material that enables selective removal of nitrate from water, and elucidation of impacts of foulants on the performance of electrochemical deionization systems.
